newsitem.title: FRANCE: Euro-MPs back call for European film fund.
newsitem.headline: Euro-MPs back call for European film fund.

text.p: The European Parliament on Tuesday backed the European film industry's call for a 200-million-Ecu European guarantee fund to help it survive competition from Hollywood productions.

"There must be an alternative to a purely American view of the world. It is not a question of preventing American films from being seen but of ensuring that they are not the only ones," French Union for Europe member Armelle Guinebertiere said in a report adopted by parliament.
The report endorses the European Commission's proposal for a fund to guarantee loans to film and television producers who want to make fiction programmes.
Under the proposal -- COM(95)546 -- the EU and the private sector would each contribute 90 million Ecus, with the European Investment Bank providing the remaining 20 million.
That capital can be expected to mobilise one billion Ecus in investments, the Commission believes.
The proposal, which has run into opposition from Germany, the Netherlands and Britain, needs the unanimous support of all 15 EU member states to become a reality.
A study released by the Commission earlier this month suggests the fund could be financially viable for 17 years.
But Guinebertiere's report notes there is still some uncertainty as to whether the fund can become self-sufficient and suggests it should begin with a five-year test phase.
Marcelino Oreja, the Commissioner responsible for audiovisual policy, told the parliament on Monday the proposal would be put to EU ministers on December 16.
